posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
Hello all, I am thinking through improvements to our team’s autonomous system, and I am unsure what tools / methods satisfy the requirements I am looking for.  Here’s the workflow that I would like:

I find our alliance partners to talk strategy for a match.  I bring a tablet / laptop to the meeting.  On that device, I have a PathPlanner-like gui where I can keyframe our robot’s autonomous path and play it back.  I have preset auto paths, but I can edit and customize any part of the path in the moment as we discuss strategy.

We decide on auto routines.  I come back to the pit and load the auto onto the driver station laptop (which stays at the pit for use in testing).  Loading the auto is done through a thumb drive, USB cord, qr code, or whatever works best.

As we prepare for the match, I can continue to edit the auto however I want, through the same gui, on the driver station laptop.  I can also edit setpoints, motor speeds, etc.  When I am done, I lock the auto, signifying that it is completed (I can unlock it and change it if need be—this is just to let the whole drive team know that the auto is ready to go).

When the robot is positioned on the field before the match and it connects to our driver station, the robot loads in the auto that is saved on the computer.  We don’t need to redeploy, and we can edit our auto in queue, during robot placement, or even during team introductions.

As someone who has only ever used Shuffleboard for auto config, I have no idea how to implement this system.  PathPlanner seems like the closest existing tool, but they specifically say not to use their hot reloading feature during competitions.  What do more advanced teams do?  Does anyone have recommendations of how to implement the system I described? Thanks for any thoughts you have.

What you could do is make a bunch of trajectories (not full paths, just segments) on pathplanner. You could then create a sort of draggable list where you can add, rearrange, or remove segments until you have comparable paths. You could add in commands wherever is appropriate.

However, there are many liabilities with this system. What if you mess up a path or forget to add segments? What if you run out of time? I’d say it’s best to create pre designed routines using pathplanner & test them, rather than making responsive autos.

posts.name: UnofficialForth

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.cooked:
I may be too conservative on my approach, but I really do not like to run autos in a match that we have not tested.  We may just slightly inch waypoints or adjust pauses, but still at least try to run those before we go live on the field even if it is just on blocks in our pit to make sure there are no surprises.

It is not always possible to test pre match and with the a-stop much less of a risk than it was in the past. But an auto that goes way wrong can wreck your entire march.

Pathplanner is an awesome tool and many times a new path/auto just works, but it seems the little things that your don’t think about until you actually see it run and go oh yeah we need to make those commands parallel and not series. Or that command never stops so our robot just sits there and does nothing often show up during testing.

I do however try to get my team to think about autos that other teams will do and make complementary autos that we have tested that can work with anyone without having to modify them pre match.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The key to making flexible software is modularity.  Don’t represent your auto routine with a monocommand; break it into parts.  You can use a tool like pathplanner to make those parts, but don’t rely on it to put them together.  It cannot really do that dynamically; you have to code that yourself.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
This is really the key. Instead of having a single path for a full autonomous, split the path into separate segments and tie them together at runtime based on the selections you make on your dashboard. Bonus points for using conditionals for picking a different segment after some decision point (such as using vision to check if your first choice game piece is available) instead of blindly following the path.

Something like this (hopefully the pseudocode gets the point across). Assumes all the trajectory segments are pregenerated and you’ve written some logic to determine which segment to follow based on known starting and target positions.

The implementation will be a lot simpler in 2027 when we can use coroutines on the new MRC, but it’s still fundamentally about breaking up a large problem into many smaller parts that can be dynamically combined. When you think about it, that’s basically the essence of software engineering.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks everyone!  This perspective is helpful.  One thing I am wondering is how people set up the interface for configuring the auto.  I could make many different paths and sequences in PathPlanner, but from what you are suggesting it seems like the actual building of your auto would be done through dropdowns in Shuffleboard.  Is there a more visual way to do it?  Ideally, I would like to be able to play through the combined sequence of autos, and see them laid out on a field map.

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked: You could make an app that lets you drag premade auto trajectories together. Then it would list the correct drop down menu settings to apply to get those trajectories.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: How would you recommend doing this?  It’s a similar project as PathPlanner, but it would be made for quick prematch configuration, and built to supply the robot with a config when it turns on  Could a part of PathPlanner be used?  Or should I build my own gui?  If I did build my own app, I would probably use Unity, as that’s what me and my coders are familiar with.  How would I handle the network tables interaction if I were to build my own app?  Thanks for your recommendation

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
what I’m suggesting is you make an app that doesn’t communicate with the robot. Instead it can translate a visual into a list of settings that you can enter into Shuffleboard. The goal here being to find a compromise between having a visual and using shuffleboard choosers to communicate to the robot.

My first thought of how to do this would be to just have a picture of the field which you can overlay various trajectories. Then write a script that corresponds the trajectories and their order into a list of selections for drop downs in Shuffleboard.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks, that makes sense.  In terms of functionality though, could this be done simply by making the auto in PathPlanner and then pasting the “.auto” json into a text input in Shuffleboard?  That would be a janky way to do it, but it would accomplish the same task, right?

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
You might be able to do that with the hotreload feature. I think something like this could work? Screenshot 2024-09-22 at 11.02.52 AM 994×366 45.2 KB

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Sort of just found this.  At the heart of this reply pull back from the Black box nature of something like Pathplanner and use the tools we have in WPILIB Command-based programming except for some form of trajectory planning, (PP or Choreo).

This will make it more modular and more customizable.  .

I’m assuming that’s the jist.

Also with the 2027 new MRC you mentioned coroutines.  Why don’t we have those now and I’m assuming the MRC will have Kotlin support?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

Why don’t we have those now

Because they’re extremely experimental and untested

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
Also with the 2027 new MRC you mentioned coroutines. Why don’t we have those now and I’m assuming the MRC will have Kotlin support?

Because OpenJDK does not implement stack frame saving (which is needed for coroutines to work) on arm32 (the roboRIO’s CPU architecture). The MRC will have a 64-bit CPU, which OpenJDK does support.

I don’t see any reason why the MRC wouldn’t be able to support Kotlin - if it can run Java, it should be able to run any JVM -based language.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We’re now fully off-topic, but is Kotlin a possible alternative for coding a robot?  How easy would it be to transfer wpilib and vendor libraries?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The only problem I could see with this approach is communication protocols at comps.  From what I’ve read, I’d guess that the hot reloading feature works by basically ssh-ing into the rio and replacing the file.  That definitely wouldn’t work when connected over FMS .  Also, the PathPlanner docs explicitly warn against using the hot reloading feature at competitions (“ PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE disable [hot reloading] at competitions ”).

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

How easy would it be to transfer wpilib and vendor libraries?

Pretty trivial.  You can/should just try it and see.

so you don’t accidentally change a path on the robot that you do not wish to.

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked: A few dozen teams used kotlin last year. It’s a nice language and pretty easy to use. There’s some warts around kotlin keywords that happen to match Java API methods, like Measure.in , but otherwise it seems pretty painless
